meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: At Debate, Mayor Is Conspicuous by His Absence Fernando Ferrer, left, the Democratic mayoral candidate in New York, and Thomas V. Ognibene, the Conservative, at a debate in Harlem last night. A lectern was reserved for Mayor Bloomberg, who skipped the event.
PAGE B1

Pataki's Ground Zero Rebuke In an extraordinary rebuke to Gov. George E. Pataki, members of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board deplored Mr. Pataki's decision to bar the International Freedom Center museum from the memorial area of ground zero while the matter was pending before the board.
PAGE B1

G.E. to Dredge the Hudson Nearly three decades after PCB's were found in the upper Hudson River, General Electric has signed a binding agreement to dredge the dangerous chemicals from 43 miles of river bottom. The project is expected to cost $700 million and take at least six years.
PAGE B3

Braves and Cardinals Win Atlanta's John Smoltz displayed his old dominating playoff form as the Braves defeated the Houston Astros, 7-1, to tie their playoff series at one game apiece. The Cardinals beat the Padres to take a 2-0 lead in their series.
SPORTSFRIDAY, PAGE D1
Stocking Up on a Flu Drug Concerned about the possibility of a flu pandemic, Congress and the Bush administration are considering spending billions to buy the influenza drug Tamiflu.
PAGE A22
New York's Legacy of Slavery An exhibition at the New-York Historical Society examines slavery's role in building and defining early New York. A review by Edward Rothstein.
WEEKEND, PAGE E43

Cervical Cancer Vaccine Is Called Highly Effective An experimental vaccine has proved highly effective at preventing cervical cancer in a two-year study involving more than 12,000 women, researchers reported.

The vaccine works by making people immune to two types of a sexually transmitted virus that cause most cases of the disease. It is the first successful vaccine ever developed specifically to prevent cancer.

The vaccine, Gardasil, is made by Merck & Company, which plans to apply for approval to the Food and Drug Administration before the end of this year and, if the vaccine is approved, to market it in 2006.
The vaccine could save many lives. Worldwide, there are about 500,000 new cases of cervical cancer a year, and 290,000 deaths.
PAGE A14

West Nile in Donated Organs Organs transplanted from a single donor in New York City infected three people with West Nile virus, leaving two of them comatose for weeks. It is only the second known case in the United States of the virus's being transmitted by organ transplant. Donors are not routinely tested for West Nile.
PAGE B1

At Debate, Mayor Is Conspicuous by His Absence Fernando Ferrer, left, the Democratic mayoral candidate in New York, and Thomas V. Ognibene, the Conservative, at a debate in Harlem last night. A lectern was reserved for Mayor Bloomberg, who skipped the event.
PAGE B1
